turn.text: Judge Mc Faton held very clearly, in a long discussion in the opinion that's set out in the appendix -- in the jurisdictional statement, excuse me, that this was not a case for a three-judge Court, and --

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: Yes, he held --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If it's not, then this Court doesn't have direct appellate jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: I understand that, Your Honor, but he didn't -- he ruled that they did have -- speculated it did have standing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, yes, but you know what he said as well as I do, or if not better.
He said that this was not a law of statewide application.
It was no more than an enabling Act.

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: The point I was making is that the Fifth Circuit did treat on that part of it, but they did not even treat the question standing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, but this isn't a question of standing.
It's a question of whether or not this Court has jurisdiction of this appeal.

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: Yes and, of course, the standing goes to the jurisdiction, as I understand it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: To the District Court's jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: I see my time is just about up.
There are two propositions that I do want to state that I believe ought to be central to the disposition of this case.
Certainly, they're essential to my argument.
One, that the right to vote is not at stake here.

What is at stake is the right of a state, under its police powers by statute, to extend any vestige of extraterritorial jurisdiction and, secondly, that when relief is sought under the Fourteenth Amendment, particularly in the interpretation of a state statute, it is only when an established or fundamental constitutional right is impinged upon by the state that strict judicial scrutiny, the compelling state interest test, or the choice of the least restrictive alternative is required.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Finnell, may I ask, do you regard any of these defendants as state officers?

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: I do not Your Honor.
In fact, I don't -- they may have been performing a state policy, but they're not performing a state function, as required in --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If they're not state officers, that would be another reason why a three-judge Court was not required, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: Well, it certainly would so.
I was really prepared to argue all of that, but I didn't have the opportunity.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well then, in any event, there was no service made on the Governor and the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: No, sir, none was made.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Did you raise any objection along that line at all?

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: I did not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Finnell.

turn.speaker: j_wagner_finnell
turn.label: Mr. J. Wagner Finnell
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: May it please the Court.
The --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do you have to say about the -- even though you've waived it, I'd like to have your comment on the lack of pervasive statewide impact here.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: The law, as I pointed out in the beginning of my argument, requires that each city enforce its police ordinances and sanitary ordinances in the police jurisdiction.
It is not simply an enabling statute.
It is a statue which requires that this be done statewide.
Every city in the State of Alabama, every town in the State of Alabama must enforce its police powers in that police jurisdiction zone.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Still, one of the cases you cited in response to a question from me earlier was Roberson against the City of Montgomery, and I have gotten that case.
And, there, the Supreme Court of Alabama describes the city's contention under Section 9, which is the state section.
The city contends that it has authority to enforce its zoning ordinances under Section 9.
Now, that sounds like an enabling Act.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: Well, as I point out, Your Honor, that may be a poor choice of words on the part of the Alabama Supreme Court.
I think the question --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But we're bound by it, aren't we?

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: Yes, sir, but I think the question presented in the Roberson case was whether or not zoning is included within the term "police power," and so --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you agree that if this is nothing more than an enabling Act, that it's improper for a three-judge Court to decide the case?

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: No, sir, I do not because I believe even an enabling Act -- I believe that the complaint, fairly read on its face, shows that the statute is being enforced or is being utilized by numerous jurisdictions around the State of Alabama and I don't think we have the factual controversy.

It's never been put in into contention by the City of Tuscaloosa either through a motion to dismiss or through an answer which has never been filed in this case, that this does not have a statewide impact.

This is not like the case of Board of Regents versus New Left Project in which the regulation, on its very face, only applied to the Texas Regent System and not to the other colleges and universities around the state.
I appreciate the Court's attention.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I have just a question for you, which I suggest you need not answer if you don't want to and you won't be prejudiced for not answering.
As I suggested to your friend, most of the complaint these days about government are paying too much and getting too little.
And, here, the people of this -- that you report to represent here, that you do represent, and the others in that area are getting a lot of free services, are they not?

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: They are getting some services, Your Honor, which perhaps might be less than if they were in the c -- costing them less than if they were in the City of Tuscaloosa.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They may have to pay twice as much for the licenses, for example.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: That, it would be.

But, they are not allowed to vote, and they consider that deprivation of the right to vote and, at the same time, the imposition of the government over them to be a commodity that doesn't have a particular price.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This is a little bit like George III, running the area from a distance.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: Something like that, Your Honor.
I've tried to stay away from Revolutionary War Rodrick in this case, but it's something like that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's strange though that the -- if that was what is so, the Revolutionary War Rodrick strains it in drafting your periphery relief.
You didn't even ask for the right to vote.
It kind of pause your case a little bit.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: No, sir.
And, I say, Your Honor, my clients made a choice about which they wanted and just as --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They don't seem to be outraged about the inability to vote.
That's the impression that comes across.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: No, sir, we pointed that out and if you'll read paragraph 10 of the complaint, we specifically say "we are denied the right to vote."
And then, we say in paragraph 11 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You don't say "we are denied the right," they don't even say that.
They say "the denial does such and such."

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: No, in paragraph 11, it says "the denial does such and such."

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Paragraph 10 just points this out.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does it?
I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: Paragraph 10 says people who live in the police jurisdiction are denied the right to vote, denied the right to participate in referenda, initiatives and recalls, that sort of thing that are allowed to other citizens in the City of Tuscaloosa.
Paragraph 11 goes on to say, as a consequence of that denial of the right to vote and the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, paragraph 10 points out as a factual matter that these people are not allowed to vote, but you never say that there's anything wrong with being not allowed to vote.

turn.speaker: edward_still
turn.label: Mr. Edward Still
turn.text: I believe that we do, Your Honor, because we say that not being allowed to vote and being governed is the conflict that creates the constitutional problem in this case.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
